lines.gurmukhi: locn kiRpn Avlokq AnUp rUp prm inDwn jwn qiRpiq n AweI hY
lines.transliteration_english: Lochan Kripan Avalokat Anoop Roopa , Param Nidhaan Jaan Tripati N Aaee Hai ?

Shabad OS B.translation: Just as the desire of a miser for money is never satiated, so are the eyes of a Sikh of the Guru who have realised that the form of True Guru is a unique treasure seeing which one never feels satisfied.

lines.gurmukhi: s√çn dwirdRI mun AMmiRq bcn piRX Acviq surq ipAws n imtweI hY
lines.transliteration_english: Sravan Daaridree Moun Anmrit Bachan Priya , Achavati Surat Piaas N Mitaaee Hai ?

Shabad OS B.translation: Just as hunger of a pauper is never satiated, so are the ears of a Gursikh which are ever desirous of hearing the ambrosial words of the True Guru. And yet hearing those elixir-like words, the thirst of his consciousness is not quenched.

lines.gurmukhi: rsnw rtq gun gurU AngRIv gUV cwqiRk jugiq giq miq n AGweI hY
lines.transliteration_english: Rasanaa Ratat Goun Guru Anagreev Goorha , Chaatrik Jougati Gati Mati N Aghaaee Hai ?

Shabad OS B.translation: The tongue of a Gursikh keeps recalling the prime traits of the True Guru and like a rain-bird who keeps shouting for more, it is never satiated.

lines.gurmukhi: pyKq suniq ismriq ibsmwd ris risk pRgwsu pRym qiRsnw bFweI hY ]621]
lines.transliteration_english: Paykhat Sounati Simarati Bisamaad Rasi , Rasik Pragaasu Praym Trisanaa Baddhaaee Hai ?621?

Shabad OS B.translation: The inner self of a Sikh is getting enlightened with blissful light through seeing, hearing and uttering of the wondrous form of True Guru-a treasure-house-nay the fountain-head of all the virtues. Yet the thirst and hunger of such a Gursikh never wanes.
